comments: I still spend way too much time on screens, but this is a great book. Cal Newport is a very compelling and engaging writer, which is a really good thing because I'm guessing I'm not the only person who needs his work whose attention span has been shredded by excessive digital media. His arguments are clear and ideas thought provoking. After reading Digital Minimalism, I liked it so much, I bought his other two books.He has an issue sometimes confusing correlation with causation when discussing research findings in order to make his point, which is surprising to me and rather disappointing given that he's clearly highly intelligent and a critical thinker, but even with this objection (a serious frustration as a scientist) the book is so good I'm still giving it 5 stars. One of the only things I've found that takes a nuanced perspective, and works to get at the root of why digital media is both the benefit and problem it is and offers solid advice on how to navigate that.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Priscilla Bettis
comments: If you don’t think you need to detox from Twitter for a month, then you probably DO.I actually started to worry while reading. What is all my online activity doing to my brain? But Newport explains with real-life solutions how you can be part of the digital world without being controlled by it.Thirty percent of the book is cited references and the index and endnotes. Newport did a LOT of research, which I appreciate because I’d rather read a book of facts than a book of just one person’s opinion.Important book, 5 stars.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Wyatt Buckingham
comments: There are a few insights in here worth reviewing, but nothing common sense didn't already inform you of: solitude is vastly important, social media is designed to keep you hooked, the attention economy doesn't give a hoot about intimacy or your analog "craft" passion projects, etc.There's an echelon (I wouldn't say genre per se) of books that are better formatted in whatever synoptic article version of them exists out there. I'd imagine The Atlantic or some similar publication summarizes his points -- just go find that and save yourself some time so you can get back to your digital-vegan woodworking project (har har har).

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Hande Z
comments: This is a very shallow book with an important message: Decrease your dependence on technology. There is no serious examination of what constitutes over-dependence on technology. The book is replete with platitudes and anecdotal stories. The author gives plenty of common-sense examples of what is good for us to do to decrease our reliance on tech devices. ‘Leave your phone at home’; take long walks; ‘join something’, like ‘junto’ a ‘mutual self-improvement club’. The entire book is more like an after-dinner talk (and a boring one too). This has unfortunately turned out like some of his other books. ‘So Good They Can’t Ignore You’ published in 2012 is one of them. His thesis of working hard to improve your craft is more important than passion is, a little suspect, to put it mildly.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Jill Hinton Wolfe
comments: I’ve always been a big fan of Newport’s (his “So Good They Can’t Ignore You” is required reading in my college course), and tried to read “Deep Work” awhile back but threw up my figurative hands in the air thinking, “This guy is a  total Luddite!” But it must have touched something in me because I bought this book, hoping it might give me some insight as to why I just couldn’t seem to focus on my myriad of passion projects, whether it be growing my small business or finishing my novel.Newport is pragmatic & straight-forward, giving readers a wide-range of practical ideas for reducing their screen time. But my favorite chapter was the one on Solitude, drawing wisdom from Thoreau and Lincoln. Today is Feb. 28 - tomorrow I start my 30 day detox experiment, which I’ll implement via a custom plan I put together with the help of this book. Wish me luck!

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Ona
comments: I bought the book to learn more about Cal Newport's approach to minimalism. Can't say that I was overwhelmed with enthusiasm. While not a bad book, I found just a little too much sales-y-ness to it. Plus, as a writer, I get some great ideas while browsing the internet. Indeed, without the Internet, earning as a freelance writer would be a lot more difficult. While disconnecting from the various digital feeds could be beneficial, and cell phones can be distinctly annoying, they do have their advantages.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Nate Wagner
comments: A philosophy of technology which you focus your online time on a small number of carefully selected and optimized activities that strongly support things you value and then happily miss out on everything else.3 simple application points:If I stopped using this technology/app all together what harm/disruption would occur in my professional/personal life?How can constrain my use of text/other apps to one time of day (batch text/email) to not allow it to impact too much of my time?Set up "conversation office hours." - I'm working on creating thisUltimately can I say that technology has made me a better person?

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: meg
comments: All of Cal Newport's books have been life-changing for me. I LOVE them. Digital Minimalism is well written and well crafted. The first section delves into the why and the second section delves into the how. Very very practical and I'm "enjoying" my digital detox with the help of Cal's book!

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: A. Maurer
comments: This book came at the perfect time in my life. I purchased when it first came out and was part of his study mentioned in the book.Did not read until now as I am working to declutter my life physically, mentally, and digitally. This book hits a key element that will lead to success and that is that this philophy will work if"the key to sustained success with this philosophy is accepting that it’s not really about technology, but is instead more about the quality of your life."and that as we remove things from our life we need to "spend this period trying to rediscover what’s important to you and what you enjoy outside the world of the always-on, shiny digital."

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Stan Sienkiewicz
comments: I read this book as it has been mentioned in many product circles. I wasn't certain if it would be of interest to me as I'm not addicted to social media on mobile devices. And I was right. Not much here for me. But there were some interesting discussions here and there especially about solitude. Not certain if you have a digital addiction this book would help. Since it's a quick read you may find a point or two worthy of the effort.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Barb Raveling
comments: I read Cal's Deep Work book, and that was so life-changing I was excited to read this newest book. I'm only halfway through but I can already tell it will be equally life-changing! I've read different things on digital declutter but what I love about Cal's book is that he approaches it from such a logical standpoint that you end up asking yourself, "What kind of life do I really want to live?" And what I find is that I'm being careless with technology-checking the Internet willy nilly whenever I want to know something among other things- and that that is not adding to the quality of my life!Cal suggests doing a 30 day digital declutter. What I like about the way he does this is that he gives clear steps on how to set up a personalized declutter based on your weak areas and what you need for work or family life. I'm an author, so I'm on the computer a lot just for my job, but I'm definitely on it more than I need to be in a way that makes my life worse not better. I'm only halfway through Cal's book but I'm super excited about how it will change my life!

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Nate R CO
comments: This is now the second book by Newport I've read in quarantine. On the first read, I found it less compelling that Deep Work but in reflecting on this and re-reading it to make notes I realize that Digital Minimalism is simply more focused and pragmatic. Newport presents a clear and alarming picture of current digital practice - and a thorough solution. His philosophy is simple in concept, counter-cultural in action, difficult to employ, but promises profound benefits for those to undertake it. These benefits aren't just personal, but promise to benefit families, workplaces, and communities. Vive la resistance!

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: nanci hobson
comments: I read Deep Work, and I like this book even better.  Cal Newport has a very easy-going, bantering writing style.  It is enjoyable to read, but you really get a lot of good advice in this book.  I find that I don't get as much done as I'd like to by the end of the day.  I'm self employed, and I work at home.  This book has really made a difference for me, as did 'Deep Work'.  I do not identify with ALL of the chapters, the one about finding meaningful ways to fill the extra time that you will have really made me laugh.  I have plenty of meaningful hobbies to fill my time with.  So I pretty much skipped that chapter.  But the rest of the book is very good.  He manages to inspire you without sounding like he is nagging you to do the right thing.  He makes you WANT to do it.  Very good writer.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: B. Hanes
comments: As a high school teacher, I have seen first hand how digital tools like smartphones can be misused and how they lead to decreased personal interactions and lack of focus.  Newport presents a good case for limiting or eliminating various social media, digital tools, web sites, etc., from your life while increasing high-quality interactions with other people and high-quality activities.  I have definitely felt a shift in my own life, almost as someone looking from the outside at how the rest of the community is functioning.  I've also made an effort to reconnect with old friends and colleagues with definite positive results and feelings in my life.A very, very good book with lots of great ideas.  Highly recommended.  As a side note, I started reading one of his other books, Deep Work.  I am also getting some great ideas from it as well!

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: ARiveraRunsThroughIt
comments: I like that it gave a lot of sound support for the steps that the author advises. It's also not a book that makes you feel bad about yourself. I like that the author concedes that everyone's "best life" will look different. The trick is getting technology to serve your values and not the other way around.Before I read this book, I was already of the "digital declutter" mindset, but I loved the case studies and also the positive affirmation of the steps I'm trying to take to take back my life.Hoping to start a "declutter" (aka digital cleanse) this weekend!

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Jorge Maldonado
comments: I would recommend this book to anyone who wants to live a more intentional and fulfilling life. I am young lawyer and creative who after grueling years of studying in law school wants to be able to succeed in his profession and make up for lost time with his family. Shedding away all the lost time using technology incorrectly will allow me to achieve my goals of maximizing my work and social life. Thanks to this book I have learned ways to use technology more intentionally and to convey this philosophy to others.10/10 would recommend.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Andrew Inge
comments: We live in a time when most children and even young adults have no remembrance of a world where no one had an all- in-one phone and sophisticated computer in their back pocket.  A world where 3 year olds didn't keep themselves occupied with their own personal iPads. A world where dinner table conversation didn't consist of everyone  putting their cell phones on the table and converse with others all over the country on any of a dozen forms of social media. Indeed, we live in a time when the world has changed and is still changing at a previously unimaginable speed.  We've never been here before, and no one knows with any certainty where we are headed or what we are going to find when we get there.But all of this is not bad.  Cal Newport does a remarkable job of sorting out the good and the bad of where we are and where we are going.  He explains how we can live in the digital world by controlling IT, and not having it control US. The way to accomplish this he calls digital minimalism.  It makes for fascinating reading, and is more than worth the effort.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: REM
comments: This book is smartly written and tackles a controversial subject, social media use. I enjoyed the examples provided throughout, as well as the author’s suggestions to reclaim your attention and direct your social media usage towards more beneficial ends. Took me a while to read because I lost attention midway through, but am glad that I finished because the book does pick up steam towards its conclusion. Would recommend to most people. Some chapters are more applicable than others based on your situation. All in all, a worthy read that outlines some truly actionable suggestions to audit your interactions with technology and arrive at a happy medium.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Derek
comments: If you have concerns about the effect mobile technologies and social media are having on your work, your relationships, and your mind, parts of this book will be give you a good case of the confirmation bias warm fuzzies. But there's actionable advice in here, too. If you've read Cal Newport before, you probably already know if his worldview and strategies resonate with you. I recommend this for everyone who feels like they're using technologies that aren't really making life better, but fears some vague calamity will befall them if they change their behavior.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Jarrett Tedesco
comments: In the half decade since crossing the threshold from academia into the "real world" there has been a constant struggle within myself to maintain the mental focus that is expected (or at least that I expect) of a young professional looking to make an honest and lasting impact in his line of work. Looking to break free from the grasp of distractions (of which I was ignorant existed at the time), I sought various sources to aid me in my quest for the reclamation of my mind. These included therapy, medication, and "life hacks", of which all listed provided only temporary relief from what "Digital Minimalism" deemed to be my true enemy: the current implementation of social media as pushed by the attention economy conglomerates!Not even half-way through the book was Cal Newport able to convince me that the bombardment on my mind from Reddit, Facebook, and Instagram were the main culprits in jumbling my brain in such a way that left me regularly unable to form the coherent thoughts needed to be thought in my line of work. In addition, I realized that the endless cycle of scrolling and clicking through low-quality information that was beginning to define every single day of my life was depriving me of the mental solitude that is absolutely necessary to maintain focus on one's goals as well as to come up with the important ideas that have lasting impacts on one's life and even the world around them!The second half of Newport's book offers a variety of practical ways that a person struggling with the distractions that come with modern technology can use to the benefit of their focus. Without giving all the book's goods away, I will say that Newport's suggestion of deleting social media off the phone has aided me the greatest out of all of his ideas. Since implementing this change, there has been a noticeable increase in my effort to engage in productive tasks, as well as a noticeable decrease in the energy needed to start these tasks.In conclusion, I believe that "Digital Minimalism" contains the answers to the problems that  many zealous yet highly distracted people face on their journey to success and happiness. This book is a beacon of hope among an electronic sea of diversions, and I recommend it without hesitation.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Angela
comments: Thus book was exactly what I needed! An eye opening book. I read this book and found myself nodding my head "yes" over and over! We are being sucked into the digital world that changes on us and we just go along for the ride. I have found myself in waiting rooms, walking down the street, in my workplace etc and everyone is like zombies staring at their phones!! Its ridiculous and we have to wake up. I walk my dog and find people out walking with their faces buried in their phones *shaking my head*. I have been so so guilty of all of this, but that is about to change. I'm committing to what Cal suggests. I deactivated all social media because I do not think the good outweighs the bad (for me)! I'm looking forward to seeing how things change in the next 30 days or so. If you too feel like you are wasting your life behind a screen....I strongly urge you to check this book out!

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Dr. Caitlin Faas
comments: I participated in the digital declutter experiment described in this book last year and thought, "I know what he's going to say in this book. Do I really need it?"The answer is yes. I'm happy to be re-energized with intentionality in my online time. I already didn't have Facebook on my phone, but this book helped me decide to delete Instagram and Twitter too. When my teenager asks why she can't have social media, now I have a clear answer.Glad to read about the science behind the default mode network. Michael Pollan also brings up that research in his latest book, How to Change the Mind. Cal Newport clearly did his homework, which I appreciate as a psychology professor.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: faithunlimited
comments: I am a big fan of Cals work. I definitely enjoyed this book more than deep work. Cal throws light on the problems and offers solutions to the issues of attention economy and digital distraction. However when it comes to solutions, I found it difficult to sustain the advice on digital declutter and my youtube app is back up. I wish he gave us more in depth advice as this is a hard problem. I wish the book was 70% more solution centric. Many practices were recommended but it would have been great to get an insiders view on how to implement those strategies and what is the core of digital declutter. I think something more radical, something like a Kon Mari for digital declutter is needed. I found Cals solutions a little diffuse all over the place and sometimes contradictory, could be confusing or overwhelming to some to implement. I hope he has a future blogpost with more ideas. I preordered the book and somehow found the youtube video on his own productivity methods to be more useful than the entire book. Maybe I am mistaken or I did not grasp the book. I would have given this 5 stars, maybe I was expecting too much..

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Todd C Cheng
comments: I had adopted, unknowingly, a few practices in this book from previous struggles. I read more books, sit more with good humans for tea, appreciate moments of no connection, watch less tv, read and watch less news, and thought I was being better on my use of social media. However I gained deeper insight, a broader palate of beneficial practices, and understanding of the wider struggles of the struggle of balancing time against mega industries that seek those eyes.This story gave me more value time. And this time is my current passion.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Nevada Williford
comments: Some have crticized this book for not saying anything “new.” My counter to that would be just because it’s old news to you doesn’t mean it’s old news to everyone else.Personally, I find the information simply and clearly presented. The author has a simple down to earth style of writing that doesn’t waste your time with lots of noise.I typically come away from one of Cal’s books motivated to think and experiment with the things he presents in my own life. Not to just blindly accept someone else’s advice, but to think, reflect, and act in my own best interest.This book is no exception. The author isn’t telling you to give up Facebook, Twitter, video games, etc. He’s simply suggesting that you engage with these things thoughtfully and intentionally. Don’t operate on autopilot when it comes to products designed specifically to take as much of your time (and sometimes money) as possible.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Brian Jones
comments: For most, the takeaways on this subject could have been adequately covered in a long article. The real substance of the book was the set up in the first 81 pages. After that the quality of the material declined quickly. That said, it’s hard to say much when one is really arguing for a more thoughtful approach to cell phone usage. Cal, I’m sure, would argue it’s much deeper and more pervasive than that, but it’s really not.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Carolien S
comments: Since reading Deep Work towards the end of last year, I have started implementing some of Cal's ideas. This book provides a number of practical steps to live a more meaningful life and accomplish much more.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: J Scott
comments: As a millennial who joined on to social media in 2005, this book is exactly what I needed. I’ve been too connected for too long without thinking through exactly why I’m so connected. Declutter, putting together a strategy and plan of how to navigate social media is definitely what I intend to do.For now, I’ll continue to let my brain rest for a while, remain detached and map out future engagement plans with the platforms that I am on. There’s definitely a healthier version to navigating social media and I believe Cal shows us the way.

prod: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
author: Gordon Allen
comments: Another informative and entertaining Newport product. I can’t sing enough praises for Cal Newport books. ‘Deep Work’ was an eye-opening game-changer for me. As useful as ‘FLOW’ in grooming me to systematically use the optimum learning experience as a tool to achieve lasting, relevant knowledge. ‘Digital Minimalism’ is a sobering study for readers, like me, who are deafened by the constant distraction and noise of personal technology. It provides a sensible process for differentiating what matters most VS pointless distractors.
